intro: Ulmus montana var. glabrata, commonly known as the smoothleaf elm, is a deciduous tree native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its smooth, pale bark and heart-shaped leaves that are typically 3–6 inches long. The tree produces small, yellowish-green flowers in early spring, followed by spherical, woody fruits. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in riparian zones and along stream banks. Due to its ornamental value and adaptability, it is sometimes planted in urban landscapes.
